Award.AwardTitle: Comparison of the Melt Distribution in Natural Analogues to Experimentally Produced Microstructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
The generation of melt in the Earth's shallow mantle, and the segregation and eruption of this melt at the Earth's surface as basalt is the main process by which the Earth continues to evolve. During melting low melting point components are separated from more refractory components, which remain behind in the mantle. The low melting point components transported to the surface with the basaltic melt include volatiles such as water and CO2. Together with the process of subduction, this exchange of the interior with the surface has shaped the composition of the atmosphere over the life of the Earth. This process also constitutes the deepest part of the plumbing systems of volcanoes in a range of tectonic settings. Understanding deep melt migration is therefore an integral part of understanding the dynamics of volcanoes.

Processes in the mantle such as the generation of melt can not be observed directly, but are interrogated experimentally as well as by studying natural occurrences of mantle rocks at the Earth's surface. The natural rocks that will be examined for this project are relatively rare in terms of their microstructure and composition. Preliminary observations indicate that a basaltic melt froze in place in rocks of mantle origin, but with an interstitial melt geometry normally observed only in experiments. Thus these rocks form an important link between experiments, direct observations in the field and indirect methods of observation such as seismic imaging of partially molten regions. This project is intended to help validate the application of experimental results on small samples at upper mantle conditions to the different scales in space and time of natural systems, leading to a better understanding the process of melt generation and transport. To this end we will examine thin sections of olivine-rich troctolites by optical and scanning electron microscopy, and collect electron-backscatter diffraction maps. Together these maps and images will be processed in the same way that images from experimentally produced samples are processed to quantify the melt distribution on the grain scale. Additional analysis by microprobe and laser-ablation mass spectrometry will help illuminate the processes that formed the microstructures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The composition of the Earth's atmosphere evolves on timescales of hundreds of thousands to millions of years through an exchange with the interior. This is facilitated by partial melting of upwelling portions; this melt is then erupted, releasing volatiles in the atmosphere. Melting and melt segregation is therefore an important process for the understanding of the long-term evolution of both the surface environment and the interior composition. The process of generation and extraction of melt in the interior can not be directly observed, and is therefore simulated through laboratory experiments. Due to the much shorter time scales of experiments compared to natural processes much more fine-grained rock samples need to be used. The experimental observations are then extrapolated to natural processes. We discovered the most extensive outcrops reported to date of natural rocks, termed plagioclase dunites, for which we infer that a melt crystallized relatively quickly in situ to form interstitial geometries similar to those found in experiments. These rocks then provide a bridge between experiments and partially molten rocks in the interior of the Earth.

We examined the geometry of the interstitial phases in the plagioclase dunites and compared it to that found in experiments to show that even if the natural rocks were not a perfectly closed system, the interstitial melt geometry of the plagiolcase dunites shows the same features as that of the experimentally produced samples. While experiments are typically cooled below the melting temperature within less then one second, natural rocks, even in shallow environments cool more slowly, resulting in some microstructural adjustments. We therefore performed experiments where we first equilibrated the samples above their melting temperature, followed by slow cooling over one week to temperatures below the melting point. Resulting features such as rounding off of some tips of early crystallizing phases found in these experiments are also observed in the plagioclase dunites, confirming the similarity of the processes involved.

Further, the composition of the main mineral, olivine, in the plagioclase dunites is the same as the composition of the source rocks for the melt in the massif, indicating that the plagioclase dunites did not originate by crystal settling in a magma chamber, but are residual from a melting process. The residual origin is further confirmed by comparison of the alignment of olivine crystals in rocks known to be from a magma chamber with the plagioclase dunites, which we infer originate in a mantle to crust transition region. Crystal settling produces a distinct alignment of crystals, which we do not observe in the plagioclase dunites. The plagioclase dunites do show crystalline alignment, but this also does not correspond to known patterns of alignment due to deformation. Instead, we infer that the olivine crystals grew during melt percolation, resulting in alignment of the grains.

Overall we conclude that partially molten rocks in the lab and the field have similar microstructures, confirming the application of physical properties measured in the laboratory to in situ partially molten rocks in crust and mantle, provided the experimental samples were microstructurally equilibrated.
